text:
Crime and Punishment

“I’ve been to this place with two floors, owned by a merchant named Yushin.”

“Yeah, those rooms…”

“It’s a gross spot—filthy, stinky, and sketchy. Crazy stuff goes down there, and all kinds of weirdos live there. But it’s cheap…”

“I can’t say much about it since I’m new to Petersburg,” Pyotr Petrovitch said, sounding annoyed. “But the two rooms are super clean, and since I’m only here for a bit… I already found a permanent flat,” he said to Raskolnikov. “I’m fixing it up. For now, I’m stuck in a cramped place with my friend Andrey Semyonovitch Lebeziatnikov at Madame Lippevechsel’s. He’s the one who told me about Bakaleyev’s house…”

“Lebeziatnikov?” Raskolnikov said slowly, as if trying to remember something.

“Yeah, Andrey Semyonovitch Lebeziatnikov, a clerk in the Ministry. Do you know him?”

“Yeah… no,” Raskolnikov replied.

“Sorry, I thought you did from your question. I used to be his guardian… He’s a nice young guy and pretty progressive. I like hanging out with young people; you pick up new things from them.” Pyotr Petrovitch looked around, hoping for a reaction.

“How do you mean?” Razumihin asked.

“In the most serious and important ways,” Pyotr Petrovitch said, clearly excited by the question. “You see,

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Pyotr Petrovitch Luzhin discusses his living situation and expresses his interest in the younger generation's ideas and perspectives.
